title: China Provides 1 Million USD Food Aid to North Korea through World Food Program in 2013 (Linked to project ID#63006 and #72146)
description: According to financial tracking service flow ID 100113, in 2013 China granted 1 million USD for the provision of food aid to the World Food Programme (WFP) to be directed to the DPRK. The flow date is December 11, 2013.  It is linked to #63006, $1m to the WFP for North Korea in 2011, and #72146, $1m in 2012.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
China Provides 1 Million USD Food Aid to North Korea through World Food Program in 2013 (Linked to project ID#63006 and #72146)

# Description
According to financial tracking service flow ID 100113, in 2013 China granted 1 million USD for the provision of food aid to the World Food Programme (WFP) to be directed to the DPRK. The flow date is December 11, 2013.  It is linked to #63006, $1m to the WFP for North Korea in 2011, and #72146, $1m in 2012.
justification: Project involves food aid and food security assistance, which is unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Provision of food aid through World Food Programme, developmental food security assistance

title: Chinese Government donates materials to China-DPRK Friendship Thaekam Cooperative Farm
description: On October 30, 2013, the Chinese Government donated a batch of materials to the China-DPRK Friendship Thaekam Cooperative Farm (中朝友谊宅庵合作农场).
staff_comments: This project supported the China-DPRK Friendship Thaekam Cooperative Farm, which is located in Sunan District, a northwestern suburb of Pyongyang (exact locational coordinates: 39.25121253771924, 125.69807219999998). More detailed locational information can be found at https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/866579392

title: Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2013
description: In 2013, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($359,096,700), AidData has taken the average price ($97.98) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2013 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
staff_comments: 1. In 2012, a North Korean source disclosed that every year ‘the Ministry of Commerce of China and the North Korean government will discuss the catalogue of aid products, quantity, period, etc., but it is basically 100,000 tons of grain, 500,000 tons of oil, and materials needed by North Korea worth 20 million US dollars.’  This annual oil donation arrangement between the Chinese Government and the North Korean Government dates back to the 1970s. On October 17, 1970, the Chinese Government and the Government of North Korea signed an Agreement on Mutual Supply of Critical Materials 1971-1976. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide the North Korean Government with 500,000 tons of crude oil per year.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2013

# Description
In 2013, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($359,096,700), AidData has taken the average price ($97.98) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2013 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
justification: Project involves donation of crude oil, a fossil fuel, and is part of ongoing oil supply infrastructure
evidence: 500,000 tons of crude oil donation, Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline infrastructure, supply to North Korea's refinery

title: Chinese government sends 16th peacekeeping mission to DRC composed of medical and engineering personnel
description: On August 7, 2013, the first echelon of the 16th Chinese peacekeeping force to Democratic Republic of Congo totaling 100 officers and men flew from the Xi’an Xianyang International Airport to the mission area to perform eight-month-long peacekeeping operations. The 16th Chinese peacekeeping force to Democratic Republic of Congo is composed of an engineer detachment and a medical detachment with a total of 218 persons. The members of the engineer detachment are from a regiment under the 47th Combined Corps of the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) and the members of the medical detachment are from a hospital of a joint logistics sub-department under the PLA Lanzhou Military Area Command (MAC).  The 10th peacekeeping team was sent in 2009 (see project #34567).
staff_comments: Peacekeeping expenditures are excluded from ODA calculations.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese government sends 16th peacekeeping mission to DRC composed of medical and engineering personnel

# Description
On August 7, 2013, the first echelon of the 16th Chinese peacekeeping force to Democratic Republic of Congo totaling 100 officers and men flew from the Xi’an Xianyang International Airport to the mission area to perform eight-month-long peacekeeping operations. The 16th Chinese peacekeeping force to Democratic Republic of Congo is composed of an engineer detachment and a medical detachment with a total of 218 persons. The members of the engineer detachment are from a regiment under the 47th Combined Corps of the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) and the members of the medical detachment are from a hospital of a joint logistics sub-department under the PLA Lanzhou Military Area Command (MAC).  The 10th peacekeeping team was sent in 2009 (see project #34567).
justification: Peacekeeping mission focused on medical and engineering support without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical and engineering personnel for peacekeeping operations, no energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides $1,632,193 for the 9th Phase of People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project (Linked to Project ID#31415, #58848, #58849, and #58853)
description: In 2013 and 2014, the Chinese Government committed $1,632,193.20 in grant funding for the 9th Phase of People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project. The purpose of this project was to maintain and repair the People's Palace (Chinese name: 人民宫) in Democratic Republic of Congo. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), $1,295,864.74 was disbursed in support of this project as of July 2019.   The French project title is 9ème Mission Technique Chinoise chargée de la maintenance du Palais du Peuple. The People's Palace Technical Cooperation Project has been undertaken in multiple phases: see the 6th phase (#31415), 7th phase (#58848), 8th phase (#58849), and 10th phase (#58853). This project is completed.
combined_text:

title: Chinese Government provides $539,187.37 grant for People's Palace Rehabilitation Design Project
description: In 2013, the Chinese Government provided a $539,187.37 grant to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for the People's Palace Rehabilitation Design Project. The purpose of this project was to design a project that would rehabilitate the People's Palace (Chinese name: 人民宫) in Kinshasa. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), $540,184.24 was disbursed in support of this project.  The French project title is Conception du projet de la réhabilitation du Palais du Peuple.

title: Chinese Government provides $561,653 for training of 55 Congolese public officials in 2013 (linked to project #58912)
description: In 2013, the Chinese Government committed $561,653.51 for two bilateral training seminars for 55 Congolese officials. It is unknown when and where the seminars were held, as well as the subject of the seminars. Eventually, $562,691.92 was disbursed for the project. A similar grant was given in 2011, which is recorded in project #58912.  The French project title is Deux séminaires bilatéraux pour 55 fonctionnaires congolais (en 2013).

title: Chinese Government provides $3,466,204 grant for Comprehensive Government Office Building Design Project (linked to projects #58940 and #58925)
description: According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform, the Chinese Government committed $3,466,204.51 in grant funding for the Comprehensive Government Office Building Design Project in 2013. This project involved the design of a four-story administrative building on Triumph Avenue in the Lingwala municipality (commune) within the Lukunga district of Kinshasa. As of July 2019, $2,083,567.79 of funding had been disbursed for this project. A separate Chinese Government loan supported the construction of the administrative building (see project #58925). The French project title is Conception du projet de construction d'un bâtiment administratif.

title: Chinese Government provides $930,740 for Martyrs Stadium Rehabilitation Design Project (Linked to projects #31415, #53459, and #58962)
description: In 2013, the Chinese Government provided a $930,740.10 grant to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for the Martyrs Stadium Rehabilitation Design Project. The purpose of this project was to design the rehabilitation of Martyrs Stadium (Chinese name: 金沙萨烈士体育场) in Kinshasa. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), $957,348.47 was disbursed in support of this project. The French project title is Conception du projet de la réhabilitation du Stade des Martyrs.  Several other Chinese Government grants were issued in support of Martyrs Stadium, including those recorded in linked projects #31415, #53459, and #58962.

title: Chinese Embassy provides $353,039.35 for Phase 4 of Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Technical Cooperation Project in N'sele
description: On August 4, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to DRC, Fan Zhenshui, went to N'sele to attend the inauguration ceremony of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Centre (also referred to as Upland Crops) (French project name: Projet de Vulgarisation Des Cultures Pluviales à Kinshasa/N'sele). The construction of basic infrastructure at the demonstration centre was completed in November 2007. Then, in 2008, the project transitioned to a technical cooperation arrangement.   The first phase of the technical cooperation was carried out from August 2009 to August 2010 by Shandong International Economic and Technological Cooperation Company. The Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) records a 2013 commitment value of $353,039.35 from the Chinese Embassy for Phase IV of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project [French project name: Coopération technique du projet de vulgarisation des cultures pluviales à N'Sele (4ème phase)]. The final amount disbursed was $363,132.18.   There are five known technical cooperation phases of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project:    Phase I: $3,420,254 (recorded in project #58963)  Phase II: $1,485,974 (recorded in project #58964)  Phase III: $673,453 (recorded in project #58965)  Phase IV: $353,039 (recorded in project #58966)  Phase V: $1,140,985 (recorded in project #58967)  There is an additional financing for the 2nd and 3rd technical cooperation phase: Phases II & III: $8,535,963 (recorded in project #58968); and a project to bring water and electricity and level the land of the site: $364,701 (recorded in project #58969).
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Embassy provides $353,039.35 for Phase 4 of Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Technical Cooperation Project in N'sele

# Description
On August 4, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to DRC, Fan Zhenshui, went to N'sele to attend the inauguration ceremony of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Centre (also referred to as Upland Crops) (French project name: Projet de Vulgarisation Des Cultures Pluviales à Kinshasa/N'sele). The construction of basic infrastructure at the demonstration centre was completed in November 2007. Then, in 2008, the project transitioned to a technical cooperation arrangement.   The first phase of the technical cooperation was carried out from August 2009 to August 2010 by Shandong International Economic and Technological Cooperation Company. The Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) records a 2013 commitment value of $353,039.35 from the Chinese Embassy for Phase IV of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project [French project name: Coopération technique du projet de vulgarisation des cultures pluviales à N'Sele (4ème phase)]. The final amount disbursed was $363,132.18.   There are five known technical cooperation phases of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project:    Phase I: $3,420,254 (recorded in project #58963)  Phase II: $1,485,974 (recorded in project #58964)  Phase III: $673,453 (recorded in project #58965)  Phase IV: $353,039 (recorded in project #58966)  Phase V: $1,140,985 (recorded in project #58967)  There is an additional financing for the 2nd and 3rd technical cooperation phase: Phases II & III: $8,535,963 (recorded in project #58968); and a project to bring water and electricity and level the land of the site: $364,701 (recorded in project #58969).
justification: Project focuses on agricultural development and technical cooperation without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Rain-fed crop demonstration center, technical cooperation phases, agricultural development focus
